text: Night had fallen. Outside, the sound of snow was as fine as sand. The fireplace burned bright, the logs crackling now and then.
I leaned against the counter. The dim yellow light illuminated half the tavern. Lucia had long gone to bed; the whole place was so quiet I could hear the wind breathing through the door cracks.
The firelight flickered, and the shadow on the wall swayed twice. I thought it was the wind—then came a soft creak from the stairs—
Alicia came down in a silver cloak, her hair catching a faint gold under the firelight. She approached the counter and pointed at the wine shelf. “Still awake? Good—pour me one.”
“Can’t sleep?”
“Mm.” she said softly. “Nights in this town are too quiet. Quiet enough to remind me of... somewhere else.”
I poured her a glass. She sat at the counter, her movements so light they barely made a sound. The amber liquid shimmered gently in the firelight.
She didn’t drink right away, just stared at the surface of the wine.
“Your wine here is strange.” She smiled. “Not like the warm kind we have in the south.”
“People here fear the cold too much. Stronger wine keeps them warm longer.”
“True.” She took a sip. “Winter in the North... can freeze even a dream solid.”
“Doesn’t sound like something a traveler would say.”
“Maybe I’m not. I came here to investigate something.”
“Something serious?”
“Maybe fate itself.” She lifted her gaze to me. The firelight caught her eyes—gray-blue, deep as a lake beneath snow.
“Or rather, destiny.” she added. The air stilled.
“Do you believe in destiny?”
“Destiny? I think it’s just something people use to make excuses for themselves.”
She chuckled softly. “That sounds exactly like something a man who sees through everything would say.”
“Not really. I just think destiny—it's too easy to use as an escape.”
“Maybe.” she murmured. “But some people never had a choice to begin with.”
I didn’t understand, but her tone felt heavy.
“And you? Are you one of those who ‘never had a choice’?”
Her hand paused at the rim of the glass. She looked like she wanted to answer—but stopped herself.
“I don’t remember.”
“You don’t remember?”
“No.” She smiled faintly. “I just feel like I’ve lived through this night many times—fire, wine, snow... and many friendly or unfriendly faces.”
My heart skipped. “What do you mean?”
She blinked. “Nothing. Just a thought from someone who’s seen too much.”
The fire crackled, and her shadow stretched across the wall. There weren’t one but two of them—one seated before me, and another faint, blurred one.
I blinked again, and they had merged into one.
“Do you know a soul leaves traces?”
“What do you mean?”
She looked into the fire. “Some say that three days after death, a person’s shadow follows the trace back to three days before.”
“It’s an ancient magic—Soul Mechanics. It lets the dead return three days into the past to rewrite their fate.”
“Sounds like a story.”
“It is. But sometimes, stories are safer than the truth.”
Her cup was empty, yet she still held it by the rim, unmoving.
“If you had the chance to relive three days,” she asked suddenly, “what would you do?”

options.text: Option A: Say seriously, “I’d try to change fate.” [Intelligence Check DC 7]
Option B: Say casually, “I’d keep running the inn as usual.” [Wisdom Check DC 5]
Option C: Ask her back, “And you? What would you want to change?” [Charisma Check DC 6]
